p.text: For the more convenient despatch of business, the Court shall be divided into—
the Court of Appeal; and
the following Divisions:—
the Common Law Division;
the Equity Division;
[s 38 am Act 19 of 1973 ss 4, 7(1) ; Act 88 of 1979 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 28 of 1985 s 3 and Sch 1(2) ; Act 172 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 10]

Intra-curial arrangements for the transaction by the Judges of Appeal of the business of the Court of Appeal shall be made by the President of the Court of Appeal with the concurrence of the Chief Justice.
Intra-curial arrangements for the transaction of the business of any Division, by the Judges appointed or nominated to that Division—
may be made by all the Divisional Judges or by a majority of those of them present at a meeting summoned for that purpose and attended by at least ten of them;
subject to any arrangement made as provided by paragraph (a) , shall be made by the Chief Justice; and

in the case of a Division of which there is a Chief Judge, but subject to any arrangement made as provided by paragraph (a) or paragraph (b) , shall, subject to subsection (2A) be made by the Chief Judge.
[subs (2) am Act 41 of 1972 s 4 ; Act 88 of 1979 s 3 and Sch 1]

Subject to any arrangement made as provided by subsection (2)(a) , a Chief Judge shall be responsible to the Chief Justice for, and be subject to the direction of the Chief Justice in respect of, the transaction of the business and the administration of the Chief Judge's Division.
[subs (2A) insrt Act 88 of 1979 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
For the purposes of subsection (2) “Divisional Judges” means the Chief Justice and all the Judges except any Judge not appointed or nominated to a Division.
This section has effect notwithstanding section 124 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 39.5] Assignment of business: immunity from challenge

heading.title: Assignment of business: immunity from challenge

p.text: The court has an implied power to organise its business in the most appropriate manner: Sedgwick v Law Society of New South Wales (NSWCA, Kirby P, 13 April 1993, unreported, BC9301933). The administrative arrangements that the court makes in relation to the assignment of judges are purely administrative matters and are not open to challenge by litigants: Rajski v Wood (1989) 18 NSWLR 512 (allegations of bias).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 40] s 40 Single Judge to constitute the Court

leg:heading.title: Single Judge to constitute the Court

p.text: All proceedings in any Division and all business arising out of proceedings in a Division shall be heard and disposed of before a Judge, who shall constitute the Court.

Subsection (1) does not affect the provisions of this Act and the rules concerning the hearing and disposal of proceedings and business before an associate Judge or before a registrar or other officer of the Court.
[subs (2) am Act 41 of 1972 s 4; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 40.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA s 101.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 35.

So far as common law trials are concerned, this section departs from the pre-1970 law under which “the court” meant the Full Court and a single judge sitting with or without a jury was de jure acting as a commissioner of nisi prius. Because of this, formerly the decision of a judge was not the decision of the court and a judge who died or retired during the course of a jury trial could simply be replaced. Under the present Act, a judge (or an associate Judge or registrar acting within their powers) is a judgment of the Supreme Court and subject to the statutory rights of appeal to the Court of Appeal conferred by SCA s 101 . However, because of s 35 of the Judiciary Act 1903 (see behind guide card “Other Legislation” in Vol 3), special leave is required to appeal from a single judge to the High Court of Australia.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 40.10] Death or incapacity of judge

p.text: Apart from instances where there is a contrary statutory provision (eg, Chua Chee Chor v Chua Kim Yong [1962] 1 WLR 1464), the ordinary rule is that once the hearing of proceedings has been commenced the same members of the court ought to conduct the hearing to the conclusion of the proceedings: R v Marrington (1850) 1 SCR (NSW) App 11 (Appendix 11); Ex parte Ryan (1864) 3 SCR (NSW) 221; Coleshill v Manchester Corp [1928] 1 KB 776; Fulker v Fulker [1936] 3 All ER 636 ; Whittle v Whittle [1939] 1 All ER 374; Munday v Munday [1954] 2 All ER 667; [1954] 1 WLR 1078 . But this ordinary rule is not involve an automatic prohibition on the reconstitution of the court and is, in any event, subject to several exceptions: Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 390; BC201210612 at [49] .

Where a judge dies after preparing reasons, but before judgment is formally delivered, the reasons may nevertheless be published: Carter Bros v Renouf (1961) 111 CLR 140; [1963] ALR 46 . If the deceased judge had not prepared reasons, judgment may be delivered by the surviving members of the court, unless there is a requirement as to the number of judges that comprise the court: Ex parte Fitzgerald; Re New South Wales Medical Board (1945) 46 SR (NSW) 111 ; contrast Ex parte Matthews (1905) SR (NSW) 131.

Where there is an aspect of the proceedings that is capable of separate determination it may be dealt with by a differently constituted court: Orr v Holmes (1948) 76 CLR 632; 22 ALJR 283; BC4800240 (costs); Wentworth v Rogers (No 3) (1986) 6 NSWLR 642 . This permissive approach has been applied to sentencing of a convicted person: R v Pepper [1921] 3 KB 167; (1921) 85 JP 264; 90 LJKB 1152; 37 TLR 863 ; the imposition of civil penalties for statutory contraventions: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Forge [2007] NSWSC 1489; BC200711472 ; final orders relating to the inspection of documents and costs: Smartec Capital Pty Ltd v Centro (CPL) Ltd [2011] NSWSC 644; BC201104692 ; Lahoud v Lahoud [2006] NSWSC 126; BC200601167 .

There are also cases where a reconstituted court has been asked to conduct the proceedings on the basis of the transcript of evidence given at the earlier hearing: Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129; [1953] ALR 528 ; Re British Reinforced Concrete Engineering Co Ltd's Application (1929) 45 TLR 186 ; Bolton v Bolton [1949] 2 All ER 908. Although such a course is open to grave objection, particularly where there is a serious conflict of evidence (see, eg, McCormack v FCT (1979) 143 CLR 284; 23 ALR 583 ), it is not correct to say that at least a superior court of record has no jurisdiction to conduct the proceedings in this way in an appropriate case: Wentworth v Rogers (No 3) (1986) 6 NSWLR 642. Where a judge dies or retires during the hearing of proceedings being heard without a jury, the proceedings must be heard de novo but the evidence already given can be read at the rehearing without the witnesses who have given it being recalled: The Forest Lake [1968] P 270 . It was doubted whether this course was properly open where the judge died during the course of a jury trial but, no objection having been raised by the parties, the appeal proceedings resulted in a verdict for the defendant, rather than an order for a re-trial: Coleshill v Manchester Corp [1928] 1 KB 776 .

In most of the cases the reconstitution of the court has been either consented to, or acquiesced in, by the parties, and that has been a material consideration: Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129; [1953] ALR 528; (1953) 27 ALJR 120; BC5300600 . But the consent of the parties is not determinative of the propriety of reconstitution if it is inherently impossible for a reconstituted court to determine the contested issues fairly and properly: Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) at [38]–[49]. It seems it is otherwise where there is a jury trial: Coleshill v Manchester Corp [1928] 1 KB 776. It may be that this rule only applies if all parties consent, the example of the rule in the cases all being matters where no one raised any objection.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 40.15] Suitors Fund certificate where proceedings aborted

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 40.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Suitors' Fund Act 1951 s 6A.

heading.title: Suitors Fund certificate where proceedings aborted

p.text: Under s 6A of the Suitors' Fund Act 1951, where any proceedings are aborted by the death or protracted illness of the judge or by some other cause outside the control of the parties, the Under Secretary for Justice may authorise payment from the fund of the costs wasted.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 40.20] Associate Judge may constitute the court

heading.title: Associate Judge may constitute the court

p.text: An associate judge, although not a member of the Supreme Court, constitutes the court for the purpose of the exercise of the powers conferred upon him or her by this Act and may exercise those powers even in matters where the court is exercising federal jurisdiction: Commonwealth v Hospital Contribution Fund of Australia (1982) 40 ALR 673; 56 ALJR 588 ; Exell v Exell [1982] VR 842 . The previous decisions of the High Court in Kotsis v Kotsis (1970) 122 CLR 69; [1971] ALR 333 and Knight v Knight (1971) 122 CLR 114; [1971] ALR 644 have now been overruled by the High Court by the Hospital Contribution Fund case.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 41] s 41 Judges in the Divisions

p.text: Subject to subsection (2) , the jurisdiction of the Court shall be exercised in the Divisions as follows—
in the Common Law Division by the Chief Judge at Common Law and such other Judges as may be nominated by the Chief Justice to act in that Division.
in the Equity Division by the Chief Judge in Equity and such other Judge or Judges as may be nominated by the Chief Justice to act in that Division;

[subs (1) am Act 19 of 1973 ss 4, 7 ; Act 88 of 1979 s 3 and Sch 1 name changed from “Divorce Division” to “Family Law Division” on 19 April 1973 ; Act 28 of 1985 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 209 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 35 ; Act 172 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 10]
Any Judge may exercise the jurisdiction of the Court in any Division with all the power and authority of a Judge appointed or nominated under this or any other Act to act in that Division.
A Judge so appointed or nominated may be appointed or nominated to act concurrently in any other Division.
[subs (4) rep Act 41 of 1972 s 4]
